title: Marine Pollution Bulletin
abstract: To elucidate the effects of the herbicide Irgarol 1051 on the gene expression of heat shock protein 90 (HSP90) in hard corals, we isolated a full-length cDNA encoding HSP90 from Acropora tenuis, which has a deduced open reading frame of 732-amino acid residues with a predicted molecular mass of 84.5 kDa. The amino acid sequence of A. tenuis HSP90 showed a high degree of similarity with the hermatypic-coral HSP90 families. After a 7-d exposure to 1 or 10 μg/L of Irgarol, the body colours of corals in the 10 μg/L treatment group were significantly whiter (bleached), whereas no such effects were observed in the corals in the 1 μg/L treatment group. However, the expression level of coral HSP90 was significantly downregulated after exposure to both 1 and 10 μg/L Irgarol. These results suggest that A. tenuis HSP90 may be a useful molecular biomarker to predict bleaching caused by herbicides.

abstract.text: To elucidate the effects of the herbicide Irgarol 1051 on the gene expression of heat shock protein 90 (HSP90) in hard corals, we isolated a full-length cDNA encoding HSP90 from Acropora tenuis, which has a deduced open reading frame of 732-amino acid residues with a predicted molecular mass of 84.5 kDa. The amino acid sequence of A. tenuis HSP90 showed a high degree of similarity with the hermatypic-coral HSP90 families. After a 7-d exposure to 1 or 10 μg/L of Irgarol, the body colours of corals in the 10 μg/L treatment group were significantly whiter (bleached), whereas no such effects were observed in the corals in the 1 μg/L treatment group. However, the expression level of coral HSP90 was significantly downregulated after exposure to both 1 and 10 μg/L Irgarol. These results suggest that A. tenuis HSP90 may be a useful molecular biomarker to predict bleaching caused by herbicides.

body_text.text: Coral reefs are one of the most productive and biodiverse ecosystems on Earth. Approximately 25% of all marine organisms depend on food and shelter provided by coral reef ecosystems, although the total area of coral reefs amounts to less than one quarter of 1% of the entire marine environment (World Meteorological Organization, 2010) . Most of the shallow-water tropical and subtropical hermatypic corals live symbiotically with dinoflagellate algae of the genus Symbiodinium (commonly called zooxanthellae). However, breakdown of the coral-Symbiodinium symbiosis is caused by various environmental stressors resulting in coral bleaching (Edmunds et al., 2003; Siebeck et al., 2006; Normile, 2016) . Previous studies have reported that coral reef ecosystems have been adversely affected by various anthropogenic impacts, such as climate change, ocean acidification, overfishing, disease, coastal development, and chemical pollutants, suggesting that many of these environmental stressors may be involved in coral bleaching (Hoegh-Guldberg et al., 2007; Burke et al., 2011) . Since the 2014-15 El Niño event, coral reefs of the world, including the Great Barrier Reef, Australia, have been in the middle of the longest extensive bleaching event on record, from 2014 to at least 2016 (Eakin et al., 2016; Normile, 2016; Hughes et al., 2017) .

In 2011, a draft genome sequence of the coral Acropora digitifera, obtained using next-generation genome sequencing, was reported for the first time (Shinzato et al., 2011) . More recently, a draft genome of Symbiodinium minutum was also decoded (Shoguchi et al., 2013) . These draft genome sequences of coral and Symbiodinium may be useful tools to investigate the molecular mechanisms of coral bleaching. Furthermore, previous studies using RNA-sequencing (RNA-seq) and DNA microarray analysis have shown changes in the gene expression profiles of corals and Symbiodinium following exposure to high water temperatures and ocean acidification (DeSalvo et al., 2008; Rodriguez-Lanetty et al., 2009; Moya et al., 2015) . Contamination by pesticides, heavy metals, and other environmental pollutants can also significantly affect the health of corals at local scales. Among these human-made pollutants, the widespread distribution of the herbicide, Irgarol 1051 (2-(tert-butylamino)-4-(cyclopropylamino)-6-(methylthio)-s-triazine; hereafter Irgarol), has been reported in marine ecosystems (Basheer et al., 2002; Konstantinou and Albanis, 2004; Lam et al., 2005; Knutson et al., 2012; Saleh et al., 2016; Sheikh et al., 2016; Harino, 2017) . Irgarol competes with plastoquinone at the quinone (Q B ) binding site of the D1 protein during photosynthesis, and inhibits the photosynthetic electron transport chain (Oettmeier, 1999) . Previous studies have demonstrated that Symbiodinium associated with corals experience rapid photophysiological stress upon short-term exposure to Irgarol at environmentally relevant concentrations of < 1 μg/L (Owen et al., 2002; Jones and Kerswell, 2003) . Our previous study, using a quantitative coral-body-colour analysis, also reported a bleaching effect in A. tenuis exposed to 1 and 10 μg/L Irgarol for 14 days (Hirayama et al., 2017) . In addition, we demonstrated an inhibitory effect on the slow component of delayed fluorescence in A. digitifera exposed to 1 μg/L Irgarol for 2 h (Katsumata and Takeuchi, 2017) . The molecular mechanisms of the bleaching effects on corals from exposure to herbicides still remain unclear, but are likely to involve the heat shock proteins (HSPs) (Rosic et al., 2011; Yuyama et al., 2012; Louis et al., 2017) .

HSPs are molecular chaperones that regulate protein structure and function during and after stress treatments, as well as under normal physiological conditions (reviewed by Hendrick and Hartl, 1993) . In various animal species, the induction of HSPs associated with resistance to multiple stresses has been reported (reviewed by Feder and Hofmann, 1999) . Among aquatic species, previous research using a slot blot immunoassay revealed that HSP70 protein levels in the marine green alga Enteromorpha intestinalis were not affected by exposure to Irgarol (0.1, 0.5, 2.5, 12.5, and 62.5 μg/L) for 96 h (Lewis et al., 2001) . A quantitative PCR assay showed that exposure to Irgarol (0.1 and 1 μg/ L for 96 h) significantly modulated mRNA expression of the HSP superfamily genes HSP20, HSP40, HSP60, HSP70, and HSP90 in the gill of the Pacific oyster (Crassostrea gigas) (Park et al., 2016) . In corals, the induction of HSP70 protein synthesis was observed in Madracis mirabilis exposed to Irgarol for 24 h (Downs and Downs, 2007) . Moreover, Yuyama et al. (2012) reported that the herbicide 3-(3,4-dichlorophenyl)-1,1-dimethylurea (Diuron), another inhibitor of the chloroplast electron transport chain, caused upregulation of the HSP90 gene in A. tenuis. However, no information is available on the effects of Irgarol on the expressions of HSP genes, such as HSP90, in A. tenuis.

The objective of this study was to elucidate the relationship between the external bleaching effects and gene expression of HSP90 in the hard coral A. tenuis in response to exposure to the herbicide Irgarol. An earlier study isolated the full-length cDNA of HSP70 in Stylophora pistillata (Tom et al., 1999) . Shinzato et al. (2011) also reported the fulllength cDNA sequence of an HSP90α-like in A. digitifera using nextgeneration genome sequencing (Shinzato et al., 2011) . However, no information is available on the nucleotide sequence and characterization of HSP90 in A. tenuis. Therefore, we initially isolated and characterized a full-length HSP90 cDNA from A. tenuis. We then investigated the association between HSP90 expression and bleaching in this coral following exposure to Irgarol. We also monitored a candidate stress-responsive gene, calreticulin (CRT), previously reported by Yuyama et al. (2012) , in the corals exposed to Diuron.

A colony of A. tenuis was purchased from Uminotane Inc. (Yomitan, Okinawa, Japan) and transported to Ehime University. These were used for the exposure experiments using 99% pure Irgarol (Wako Pure Chemical Industries, Ltd., Osaka, Japan) following our previously described method (Hirayama et al., 2017) . The exposure concentrations 1 or 10 μg/L of Irgarol were selected based on the findings of our previous study (Hirayama et al., 2017) . After two weeks of acclimation, the cut apical coral branches (~1 cm long, n = 4 per group) were exposed to the two concentrations of Irgarol in Petri dishes (ca. 80 cm ) for 7 d. The control artificial seawater (34 psu) containing LIVEsea salt (Delphis Inc., Itami, Hyogo, Japan) and solvent control (0.001% acetone in artificial seawater) groups were also prepared according to our previously established protocol (Hirayama et al., 2017) . Test solutions and Petri dishes were changed every two days. During the experimental period (i.e., 7 d of herbicide exposure) corals were maintained at 27.5°C under a 12:12 h (light: dark) photoperiod, illuminated using an LED light (50 μmol m −2 s −1 ). At the end of the experimental period, corals were preserved in RNAlater solution (Qiagen, Tokyo, Japan), and stored at −80°C until total RNA isolation.

The body colours of corals were monitored using a digital colour imaging system according to our previously described method (Hirayama et al., 2017 ). The camera system comprised a commercial grade digital single-lens reflex camera, Nikon df (Nikon Corporation, Tokyo, Japan) with AF-S Nikkor 50 mm lens (Nikon Corporation, Tokyo, Japan), and a wireless speed light system, SU-800 Wireless Speedlight Commander (Nikon Corporation, Tokyo, Japan) fitted with the Wireless Remote Speedlight SB-R200 (Nikon Corporation, Tokyo, Japan) and covered with the Extreme Close-Up Positioning Adapter SW-11 (Nikon Corporation, Tokyo, Japan). Corals were photographed manually using a digital camera on each day of the experimental period. Photographic images of the corals were converted into RGB (R, red; G, green; B, blue) values using Adobe Photoshop CC (Adobe Systems Incorporated, San Jose, California, USA) based on NEF (RAW) files. The body colour of each coral was quantified as the sum of each R, G, and B value (ranging from 0 to 255), for example, white is expressed as R = G = B = 255, and black as R = G = B = 0. Thus, increases in RGB values indicate changes in the coral body colours towards white, indicating a 'bleaching' effect.

After homogenizing the A. tenuis samples using TissueLyser II (Qiagen, Tokyo, Japan), total RNAs were isolated using an RNeasy Mini kit (Qiagen, Tokyo, Japan). Poly(A) + RNA was purified using a Dynabeads mRNA Purification kit (Thermo Fisher Scientific K.K., Kanagawa, Japan). The specific forward (5′-AAAACCCTTGTGGAT GCG-3′) and reverse (5′-GATGCGACTGGCATGAACT-3′) primers for partial cDNA cloning of A. tenuis HSP90 were designed from the highlyconserved nucleotide sequences of cnidarian HSPs, such as A. digitifera HSP90α-like (GenBank accession no. XM_015908105), Orbicella faveolata HSP90β-like (XM_020762710), Nematostella vectensis HSP90 (XM_001640639), and Exaiptasia pallida HSP90α-like (XM_021041069). One hundred nanogram of poly(A) + RNA was reverse transcribed into cDNA using a ReverTra Ace qPCR RT Kit (Toyobo, Osaka, Japan), and cDNA was amplified using PCR with a KOD Plus Neo PCR system (Toyobo, Osaka, Japan). The thermo-cycling profile used was: 94°C for min, followed by 40 cycles of 98°C for 10 s, 68°C for 1 min, and a final extension at 4°C. The PCR products were visualized using gel electrophoresis with a 2% agarose gel and Midori Green Direct (NIPPON Genetics, Co., Ltd., Tokyo, Japan) staining. Bands with appropriate molecular sizes were excised from the gel and purified (Qiagen, Tokyo, Japan). The amplified PCR fragments were separately cloned into a pGEM-T easy vector (Promega, Madison, WI, USA) to transform the competent DH5α cells according to the manufacturer's instructions. After the transformation, positive colonies were sequenced using a BigDye Terminator v3.1 Cycle Sequencing Kit and the Genetic Analyzer ABI3130 automatic sequencer (Thermo Fisher Scientific K.K.). The 5′-and 3′-ends of the HSP90 sequence were amplified using the rapid amplification of the cDNA end (RACE) technique using a Marathon cDNA Amplification Kit (Clontech, Palo Alto, CA, USA). Gene-specific primers designed for the 5′-RACE (5′-GACCTTCAACCGA AAAGTGC-3′) and the 3′-RACE (5′-AAAACCCTTGTGGATGCG-3′) were coupled with adaptor primers during the PCR reactions. Cloning and sequencing of these PCR products were performed following the aforementioned protocols. To determine the full-length HSP90 sequence, at least five clones of each PCR product were finally sequenced.

The cDNA sequence was analysed for similarity with other known Fig. 2 . Phylogenetic analysis of amino acid sequences of HSP90s from various species. Accession numbers used were as follows: Acropora digitifera HSP90αlike (XP_015763591), Acropora tenuis HSP90 (LC314154), Alligator mississippiensis HSP90β (BAF94147), Anopheles albimanus HSP82 (AAB05639), Crassostrea gigas HSP90 (ABS18268), Danio rerio HSP90α (NP_571403), Danio rerio HSP90β (O57521), Drosophila melanogaster HSP82 (CAA27435), Dugesia japonica HSP90 (ACM91724), Escherichia coli B354 HSP90 (EFF14283), Exaiptasia pallida HSP90α-like (XP_020896728), Gallus gallus HSP90α (P11501), Gallus gallus HSP90β (CAA49704), Homo sapiens HSP90α (NP_005339), Homo sapiens HSP90β (NP_031381), Nematostella vectensis HSP90 (XP_001640689), Orbicella faveolata HSP90β-like (XP_020618369), Penaeus monodon HSP90 (ACO83357), Portunus trituberculatus HSP90 (ACQ90225), Rattus norvegicus HSP90α (NP_786937), Rattus norvegicus HSP90β (P34058), Tigriopus japonicus HSP90 (ACA03524), and Xenopus laevis HSP90β (AAV41061). The sequence of Escherichia coli B354 HSP90 was used as an out-group. sequences using the Basic Local Alignment Search Tool (BLAST) program. The deduced amino-acid sequence was analysed using the MacVector version 15.1.5 program (CereBioscience, Inc., Saitama, Japan), and the predicted molecular mass and theoretical isoelectric point (pI) were also calculated. Multiple alignments of the amino acid sequences of HSP90 were performed using ClustalW analysis. A phylogenetic tree was constructed using a neighbor-joining method in MEGA7.0 (Kumar et al., 2016) . Bootstrap values based on 1000 replications were calculated. Positions with gaps were excluded, and corrections were made for multiple substitutions.

The expression levels of the target genes were measured using quantitative reverse-transcription-polymerase chain reaction (qRT-PCR) using the Fast SYBR Green Master Mix (Life Technologies Japan Ltd., Tokyo, Japan) and StepOne™ Real-Time PCR System (Life Technologies Japan Ltd.). The primer sequences for HSP90, CRT, β-actin, and β-tubulin (Yuyama et al., 2012) and details of the qRT-PCR assay are provided in Table S1 (Supporting Information). Reaction mixtures were incubated at 95°C for 20 s, followed by 40 PCR cycles of 95°C for 3 s and 60°C for 30 s. Following qRT-PCR, the specificity of the target gene amplification was determined using melting curve analysis to discriminate target amplicons from primer dimers or other nonspecific amplicon products. The mean threshold cycles (as determined by the linear portion of the fluorescence absorbance curve) were used for the final calculation of gene expression levels. These data analyses were conducted according to the MIQE guidelines (Bustin et al., 2009) . To further assess the expression stability of two candidate reference genes, i.e., β-actin and β-tubulin (Yuyama et al., 2012) , the geNorm expression stability (M) and the coefficient of variation values (CV) were calculated using the geNorm software (https://genorm.cmgg.be) (Vandesompele et al., 2002) . The M (0.23) and CV (0.08) values of βactin were lower than that of β-tubulin, suggesting a more stable expression of β-actin gene. Thus, the expression levels of the target genes were normalized to that of β-actin mRNA. All analyses were performed Fig. 3 . Alignment of amino acid sequences deduced from Acropora tenuis, Orbicella faveolata, Exaiptasia pallida, Nematostella vectensis, and Acropora digitifera HSP90 cDNAs. Accession numbers used were: A. tenuis (LC314154), O. faveolata (XP_020618369), E. pallida (XP_020896728), N. vectensis (XP_001640689), and A. digitifera (XP_015763591). The HSP90 family signatures and MEEVD consensus sequences of HSP90 are boxed. The ATP-binding GxxGxG motif, the lysine-rich nuclear localization signals, and the protein-binding leucine-zipper Lx6Lx5Lx6Lx6L motif are in pink, red, and green, respectively. (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.) in triplicate for each gene in each sample.

All the statistical analyses were performed using GraphPad Prism ver.7.0 (GraphPad Software, San Diego, CA, USA). All data were tested for normality using the Kolmogorov-Smirnov test, and for variance in homogeneity using the F-test or Bartlett's test. The Student's t-test was used to determine whether differences existed between the control and solvent control groups; as no significant differences were observed, the solvent control groups were used for subsequent analyses. The differences in the RGB values or gene expression levels between the solvent control and Irgarol treatment groups were analysed using parametric one-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) followed by Dunnett's multiple comparisons tests. Pearson's correlation test was used to examine the relationships between the expression levels of the HSP90 and CRT genes. Results were considered statistically significant at p < 0.05.

The full-length cDNA of the A. tenuis HSP90 was 2562 bp, including a 5′-terminal untranslated region (UTR) of 67 bp, a 3′-terminal UTR of bp, with a typical polyadenylation signal sequence (AATAAA) and poly (A) tail, and a deduced open reading frame (ORF) of 2196 bp, encoding 732-amino acid residues with a predicted molecular mass of 84.5 kDa and theoretical pI of 4.64 (Fig. 1) . This complete sequence is deposited in GenBank under the accession no. LC314154.
body_text.section: Molecular cloning and characterization of A. tenuis HSP90

body_text.text: We constructed a phylogenetic tree using the amino acid sequences of HSP90s from vertebrates, insects, molluscs, crustaceans, cnidarians, flatworms, and bacteria. Results showed that the HSP90 isolated from the A. tenuis sample was positioned with the HSP90s of cnidarian species, and belonged to the same group as the A. digitifera HSP90α-like (Fig. 2) .
body_text.section: Molecular cloning and characterization of A. tenuis HSP90

body_text.text: We compared the amino acid sequences of HSP90s among cnidarian species (Fig. 3) . The amino acid sequence of the A. tenuis HSP90 showed high similarities with O. faveolata HSP90β-like (97.3%), A. digitifera HSP90α-like (96.5%), E. pallida HSP90α-like (93.4%), and N. vectensis HSP90α (93.1%). Five conserved HSP90 family signatures were identified in the deduced amino acid sequence of A. tenuis HSP90: signature 1, NKEIFLRELISNSSDALDKIR (39-59); signature 2, LGTIAKSGT (106-114); signature 3, IGQFGVGFYSAYLVAD (130-145); signature 4, IKLYVRRVF (358-366); and signature 5, GVVDSEDLPLNISRE (384-398) (Fig. 3) . The MEEVD consensus sequence of HSP90 was also conserved between A. tenuis and the other cnidarian species, except for A. digitifera (Fig. 3) . Furthermore, the ATP-binding GxxGxG motif, lysine-rich nuclear localization signals, and protein-binding leucinezipper Lx6Lx5Lx6Lx6L motif were identified (Fig. 3) .
body_text.section: Molecular cloning and characterization of A. tenuis HSP90

body_text.text: In the control, solvent control, and 1 μg/L Irgarol treatment groups, the RGB values of corals remained stable during the 7-d exposure period, and no significant differences were observed among these groups (Fig. 4A) . However, in the 10 μg/L Irgarol treatment group, a significant increase in the RGB values of corals compared to the solvent control group was observed from day five until the end of the experimental period (Fig. 4A) , although the corals did not reach the fully bleached stage by day seven of the experiment (Figs. 4B and C) . At the end of the experimental period, the RGB values of the corals exposed to μg/L Irgarol were significantly higher than those of the corals in the Fig. 4 . RGB values of Acropora tenuis during (A) and after the exposure (B) to Irgarol. (C) Photographs of corals on Day 0 and Day 7 of Irgarol exposure. Corals (n = 4 per group) were exposed to the nominal concentrations of 1 or 10 μg/L Irgarol for 7 days. Values are shown as the mean RGB values, and bars represent the standard deviations from the means. Asterisks * and ** denote a significant difference compared with the solvent control group at p < 0.05 and p < 0.01, respectively. solvent control group (p < 0.01), while the RGB values of the corals exposed to 1 μg/L Irgarol showed no significant differences from those of the corals in the solvent control group (Fig. 4B) .
body_text.section: Body colour analysis of corals exposed to Irgarol

body_text.text: We designed specific primers to quantify the A. tenuis HSP90 gene cloned in this study, and assessed the assay performance using a qRT-PCR method. The PCR efficiency of HSP90 was calculated as 92.6%, and that of CRT and β-actin were 88.7% and 85.0%, respectively (Table S1 ). We also attempted the specific detection of the A. tenuis HSP90 gene using specific primers for qRT-PCR. Results showed that although specific detection of the coral HSP90 gene was observed, no PCR product was observed in the Symbiodinium HSP90 plasmid (Fig. S1 ), suggesting that the specific primer pairs designed in this study could be used to quantify the A. tenuis HSP90 gene. The primers for Symbiodinium HSP90 previously reported by Rosic et al. (2011) , were also specific to the Symbiodinium HSP90 plasmid (Fig. S1 ).
body_text.section: Expression analysis of HSP90 and other genes

body_text.text: No significant differences were observed between the mRNA expression levels of the HSP90 and CRT genes in the control and solvent control groups; therefore, all treatment groups were compared to the solvent control group. Our qRT-PCR analyses revealed that the expression of the HSP90 gene in corals was significantly downregulated by exposure to 1 and 10 μg/L Irgarol in a dose-responsive manner (p < 0.001) (Fig. 5A) . In addition, the expression level of CRT was also significantly downregulated by exposure to 1 and 10 μg/L Irgarol (p < 0.05 and p < 0.01, respectively) ( Fig. 5B) . A significant relationship between HSP90 and CRT gene expressions was also observed (p < 0.0001) (Fig. 5C ).
body_text.section: Expression analysis of HSP90 and other genes

body_text.text: Shinzato et al. 2011reported the first draft genome of A. digitifera decoded using an RNA-seq analysis. However, the molecular mechanisms of coral bleaching resulting from various stresses, including exposure to herbicides, remain unclear, but are likely to involve the HSPs, including HSP90 (Louis et al., 2017) . Furthermore, no data is available for the molecular characterization of HSP90 in coral species, although two full-length cDNA sequences of HSP90 are available for O. faveolata and A. digitifera. In this study, we successfully isolated a full-length HSP90 cDNA from A. tenuis. Phylogenetic analysis revealed that the HSP90 isolated from A. tenuis was positioned with the HSP90 of cnidarian species, sharing the greatest sequence homology with A. digitifera HSP90α-like. In addition, comparison of the amino acid sequence of A. tenuis HSP90 with that of the other cnidarian HSP90s revealed high similarity (93-97%) between the HSP90s of A. tenuis and that of A. digitifera, O. faveolata, E. pallida, and N. vectensis, suggesting a conserved amino acid sequence of HSP90 among cnidarian species. In the deduced amino acid sequence of A. tenuis HSP90, we identified five conserved HSP90 family signatures and the MEEVD consensus sequence, which concurs with the findings of previous studies (Chen et al., 2006; Sonoda et al., 2006) . The ATP-binding GxxGxG motif, lysine-rich nuclear localization signals, and protein-binding leucinezipper Lx6Lx5Lx6Lx6L motif were also identified. These results suggest that A. tenuis HSP90 acts as a molecular chaperone that regulates protein structure and function during and after stress, as well as under normal physiological conditions (reviewed by Hendrick and Hartl, 1993) .

Irgarol is categorized as a photosystem II (PSII) herbicide, as it inhibits the chloroplast electron transport chain (Draber et al., 1991; Oettmeier, 1999; Jones, 2005) . Several earlier studies have clearly demonstrated that Irgarol causes rapid photophysiological stress in corals and Symbiodinium after short-term exposures to environmentally relevant concentrations of < 1 μg/L (Owen et al., 2002; Jones and Kerswell, 2003) . This study revealed that significant increases in the RGB values (i.e. coral body colour became whiter) were observed in corals exposed to 10 μg/L Irgarol for 5 d, compared to the corals in the solvent control group, whereas no significant increases in the RGB values were observed in the corals exposed to 1 μg/L Irgarol for 7 d. Our previous study has also showed that a significant increase in RGB values was observed in A. tenuis exposed to 1 μg/L Irgarol for 8 d and in those exposed to 10 μg/L Irgarol for 5 d (Hirayama et al., 2017) . Together, these studies indicate that the body colour of corals becomes whiter following exposure to 10 μg/L Irgarol over 5 d.

Numerous molecular analyses of coral HSP90 have demonstrated the expression of the HSP90 gene during thermal stress, and suggested that the modulation of HSP gene/protein expression in corals is a Fig. 5 . Messenger RNA expression levels of Acropora tenuis HSP90 (A) and CRT (B) quantified using qRT-PCR, and the correlation between HSP90 and CRT gene expression levels (C). Corals (n = 4 per group) were exposed to concentrations of 1 or 10 μg/L Irgarol for 7 days. The whiskers show maximum and minimum values, the boxes show upper and lower quantiles, and the black line indicate the medians (normalized to β-actin mRNA expression). Asterisks *, **, and *** denote significant differences compared with the solvent control group at p < 0.05, p < 0.01, and p < 0.001, respectively. Cont.: control; S.C.: solvent control.

potential biomarker of exposure to heat stress (reviewed by Louis et al., 2017) . For example, microarray analyses have demonstrated that HSP90 in adult O. faveolata was slightly upregulated (1.28-fold increase) after exposure to thermal stress (32°C over 11 d) than under the control temperature (29°C) (Desalvo et al., 2008) . Similarly, cDNA microarray analysis showed upregulation of HSP90 in larval A. millepora after 3 h of exposure to 31°C (compared to that in the controls at 24°C) (Rodriguez-Lanetty et al., 2009) . Leggat et al. (2011) reported that exposure to 32°C for 5, 7, and 8 d caused 1.5, 4.9, and 10.5-fold upregulation of A. aspera HSP90, respectively, compared to that in the controls maintained at 28°C. More recently, Kenkel et al. (2013) documented the downregulation of HSP90 expression in colonies of bleached Porites astreoides exposed to thermal stress (31°C) for 6 wk. However, limited studies have reported the effects of herbicides, such as Irgarol, on coral HSPs, including HSP90. A preliminary study on the short-term cellular toxicological responses of the coral Madracis mirabilis to acute 10 μg/L Irgarol exposure for 24 h (Downs and Downs, 2007) showed that coral HSP70 protein synthesis was significantly induced, whereas no change in the protein synthesis of HSP60 was observed. Previous research has also revealed that HSP70 protein levels in the marine green algae E. intestinalis were not affected by exposure to Irgarol (0.1, 0.5, 2.5, 12.5, and 62.5 μg/L) for 96 h (Lewis et al., 2001 ). In the Pacific oyster (C. gigas), Irgarol exposures (0.1 and 1 μg/L for 96 h) significantly modulated mRNA expression of the HSP superfamily genes HSP20, HSP40, HSP60, HSP70, and HSP90 in the gill (Park et al., 2016) . These differential HSP expressions in animals in response to Irgarol exposures imply differences in the effects of variable durations of exposure and the HSPs targeted among different species. In our study, the qRT-PCR analyses clearly indicated that A. tenuis HSP90 transcription levels were downregulated by 7-d exposure to 1 and μg/L Irgarol. Moreover, we demonstrated that the RGB values of corals significantly increased in the 10 μg/L Irgarol treatment group. These results suggest that Irgarol may affect the expression and function of A. tenuis chaperon proteins, such as HSP90, which may be involved in the resultant coral bleaching. Conversely, the body colours of corals were not affected by exposure to 1 μg/L of Irgarol. This suggests that A. tenuis HSP90 may be a useful molecular biomarker of the bleaching effects of herbicides such as Irgarol.

Although this study documented the modulation of HSP90 involved in the potential bleaching of A. tenuis exposed to Irgarol, the molecular mechanisms of bleaching remain to be fully elucidated. Yuyama et al. (2012) surveyed the stress-responsive genes in A. tenuis exposed to Diuron (another PSII inhibitor) using a high-coverage cDNA expression profiling (HiCEP) and/or qPCR assay, and identified genes for oxidative stress response protein, aquaglyceroporin, CRT, and methionine adenosyltransferase, including HSP90. This study focused on the highest upregulated gene among these Diuron-responsive genes, CRT (Yuyama et al., 2012) . CRT is a calcium binding chaperone and plays an important role in the folding of newly synthesized proteins (Saito et al., 1999) . In this study, the expression level of CRT, as well as HSP90, was significantly downregulated by exposure to 1 and 10 μg/L Irgarol. Results also showed that the mRNA expression level of HSP90 in corals was positively correlated with that of CRT. Yuyama et al. (2012) reported that the mRNA expression levels of CRT were upregulated in juvenile A. tenuis polyps exposed to high temperature (32°C for 27 h) or Diuron (10 μg/L for 13 d). These results suggest that A. tenuis CRT may be a candidate biomarker gene for exposure to herbicides.

In addition, several studies have demonstrated that the mRNA expression level of coral HSP90 is altered by other environmental chemicals. Venn et al. (2009) reported that the expression of HSP90 was upregulated in Montastraea franksi exposed to copper at concentrations of 30 and 100 μg/L for 8 h. Tributyltin (TBT), an antifouling biocide, also modulated HSP90 expression in A. tenuis (Yuyama et al., 2012) . The response of coral HSP90 and other HSPs to other human-made pollutants remains to be evaluated. However, the significance of identification of these molecular biomarkers, including HSP90, in corals still remains poorly evaluated. This may be due to the limited information about the molecular functions of these biomarker genes. Most studies have focused on gene expression analysis of biomarkers (Louis et al., 2017) . Further studies are needed to clarify the molecular functions of the biomarker genes in corals, and these findings will provide insights into the prediction of bleaching and the potential risks corals face from environmental contaminants including herbicides.

In conclusion, we isolated a full-length cDNA encoding HSP90 from A. tenuis, which had a deduced ORF of 732-amino acid residues with a predicted molecular mass of 84.5 kDa. Comparison of the amino acid sequence of A. tenuis HSP90 with that of the other cnidarian species revealed high similarities between A. tenuis HSP90 and the HSP90s of O. faveolata (97.3%), A. digitifera (96.5%), E. pallida (93.4%), and N. vectensis (93.1%). After a 7-d exposure to 1 and 10 μg/L of Irgarol, the body colours of corals were significantly whiter in the 10 μg/L Irgarol treatment group, suggesting a potential bleaching effect from exposure to Irgarol. Our qRT-PCR analyses revealed that the expressions of the coral HSP90 and CRT genes were significantly downregulated by exposure to both 1 and 10 μg/L Irgarol, although coral colour was not significantly different in the 1 μg/L Irgarol treatment group compared to that in the solvent control group. Our findings suggest that A. tenuis HSP90 may be a useful molecular biomarker to predict the bleaching effects of herbicides, such as Irgarol.

back_matter.text: This study was supported by Grant-in-Aid for Scientific Research (B) (no. 26281048) from the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science (JSPS KAKENHI), Japan. The authors express their sincere thanks to Dr. A. Iguchi and Dr. N. Tominaga for suggestions on total RNA extraction from the coral samples.
Supplementary data to this article can be found online at https:// doi.org/10.1016/j.marpolbul.2018.06.014.

FIGREF0.text: Nucleotide and deduced amino acid sequences of Acropora tenuis HSP90 (GenBank accession no.: LC314154). The start codon (ATG) and the termination codon (TAG) are boxed. The typical polyadenylation signal sequence (AATAAA) in the 3′-untranslated region is in bold letters and underlined. Numbers on both sides correspond to nucleotide positions.
